div.p:
There are no reasonable bounds to my joy and exultation - that you should be promoted was your right as an officer, that you should be promoted insuch an distinguished manner is due to your real unobtrusive merit; which I have always known how to appreciate and which I sincerely rely on for your Future advancement above your fellow's - I take some subordinate pleasure in being conscious that I always foretold what has now hap- -pened happened & that it does not a- -rise arise merely from my being of a sanguine temper but from the exertion of some of those prophetic powers that are attained by old experience - To morrow is my 66 th. birth day & Maria in her secret
heart, but she dare not say so, wishes that your letter had come a day later. Indeed I do not think that your sisters felt more pleasure at hearing ofyour promo -tion promotion than she did - I have the remainder of the sheet to the congratulations of some of the most warm hearted ladies I have ever known of whom Mary Sneyds is not the coldest. -

We do indeed my dearest brother most unanimous -ly unanimously rejoice that you are likely to be so soon placed in the situation where you ought long ago to have been placed, both from the exertions of your body and the powers of your mind; and that it has been done in such a manner as to satisfy even your own proud heart - and proud enough God knows you are I have not told you yet how greatly MrEdgeworth was delighted with your independant refusal to ax a peer for anything but an axe. I never will ask you again to pay court to any one so dont be afraid - and Ill tell you my reason why - Because I find you get on better without it. - I would send you a copy of Mr Croker's very hand some letter if I did not believe that Louisa had already done so - but I will conclude with his words "I never happened to hear - of a gentleman so generally and so highly commended as he is - May God preserve your life both for your country & your friends FE

To tell you my most dear brother that my heart is rejoiced at your certainty of promotion would be to tell you what you know; I can only say that you have my warmest congratulations, & wishes, that your promotion may be a source of happiness to you, & that you may continue the same excellent hero & be long preserved to all your friends & to your own attach'd friend H Beaufort
May your happiness my kind & excellent friend increase with your promotion - you cannot be more esteemed & beloved by those who know your merits than you have ever been - M. Sneyd
I cannot find better words nor any more entirely suited to my own senti- -ments sentiments & feelings my dear Capt Beaufort than dear Mary has used to which with all my heart I sub scribe C Sneyd

My father has said for me and in the best man- ner every thing that I could say for myself - And I have only to assure you my dear Fran- -cis
Francis
that he has told you exactly the truth, - I congratulate you upon your promotion being made in the manner you desired & deserve, - not the result of any little di or patronage -

All the men who served under you on -phic duty are invited by my father to this day to celebrate their Captain's promo- -tion promotion - It will give you pleasure to hear that such as you made them they have continued punctual, orderly, useful men,- who are now employed by my father in his Bog-survey'ing and are able to earn each 3 shillings a day - which they do not turn into whiskey -

How happy poor Quin must be! - I have just written to his mother to tell her the good news - I think you have in store a solid fund of selfsatisfaction in the thoughts of the good you have done that young man - And in this & every source of happiness to you I rejoice

postscript.p: I advise you to read Alfieri's life
